summary: This research paper critiques the conventional understanding of enthalpy changes in chemical reactions, particularly the common assumption that the change in enthalpy (Delta H) is equivalent to the heat exchanged at constant pressure (q(p)). The author argues that while this simplification is valid for spontaneous reactions, it fails for non-spontaneous reactions due to the implications of the second law of thermodynamics. The paper emphasizes the necessity of including nonexpansion work (w(additional)) in the analysis of enthalpy changes, proposing that Delta H does not equal q(p) for non-spontaneous reactions. Furthermore, the significance of nonexpansion work in various biological and technological processes is highlighted, advocating for revisions in educational resources to better reflect these complexities.
